main.div: Adds the given node(s) as content to the list elements as additional nodes.

dl.dd: a text to add as text node of the list elements

a function that will be invoked for each list element to determine its content. The function can return either a string for a text node, an HTML element or a list containing strings and/or HTML elements.
content to add only to the first element of the list. The content can be a string for a text node, an HTML element or a list containing strings and/or HTML elements.

main.div: Adds the given node(s) as content to the list elements as additional nodes. Unlike add(), the new nodes will be the first children of the list items. If a string has been given, it will be added as text node to all elements. If you pass an element or a list, it will be added only to the first element of the list. In order to add elements to several list items, you need to pass a factory function(element, index) thats creates new instances for each item. The function will be invoked for each element and may return either a string for a text node, a simple HTML element or a list containing both.

div.div:
Using the following HTML:
Here is some text.
Add a text to the given 'comment' div: $('#comments').addFront('Some additional text. '); This results in:
Some additional text.Here is some text.

Using the following HTML:
  • First list entry
  • Second list entry
The following Javascript adds an element to the list: $('#myList').addFront(EE('li', 'My extra point')); This results in
  • My extra point
  • First list entry
  • Second list entry

Use a list to add several elements at once:
$('#comments').addFront([EE('br'), 'Some text', EE('span', {'className': 'highlight'}, 'Some highlighted text')]);

If you need to add an element or a list to more than one element, you need to provide a factory function:
$('.chapter').addFront(function(e, index) { return EE('div', 'Scroll down for the next chapter.'); });
